awd_titl_txt: Engineering Phonons in Hybrid Nanostructures by Design and Understanding Their Roles in A Few Physical Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract
Phonons are the collective vibrations of the atoms in a solid and can be thought of as particles moving though the solid.  They are responsible for many properties such as the thermal conductivity and thermal expansion of materials.  They even play a role in how materials will perform in new applications such as for quantum computing.  Understanding, and even harnessing, how these particles interact with each other is essential for designing and optimizing new materials. This project focuses on understanding how phonons interact in a few select physical processes. This research is accomplished by employing multidisciplinary experimental tools, ranging from materials design and synthesis of colloidal quantum structures to ultrafast optical spectroscopy, and it thus provides a fertile ground for students' training, K-12 outreach and curriculum development. 

Technical Abstract
This project supports an experimental activity with a goal to understand phononic interactions at the nanoscale and to address a few phonon-mediated fundamental processes by adopting a multi-pronged experimental approach. It particularly combines ultrafast optical spectroscopy with pre-designed colloidal hybrid nanostructures that can possess well-defined nanoscale interface topology for phonon engineering. This research directly involves graduate students training in tools and techniques needed to address a few fundamental issues: effect of interfacial symmetry (centrosymmetric vs. non-centrosymmetric interfaces) on nanoscale phonon characteristics; all optical control of interfacially coupled phonons and their interplay in time domain; understanding interactions between optically excited phonons and other quantum dynamics. Accomplishment of this project should advance our nanoscale materials engineering capability and new design guidelines for desirable phonon properties, as well as our understanding of phonon-dependent physical processes. This work is additionally important because hybrid nanostructures with well-defined interface topology for phonon engineering can be utilized as building blocks for functional phononic devices. In addition to graduate and undergraduate students' laboratory training, this project also allows for integrated education platform with cutting-edge research activities in classroom and various outreach activities with particular focus on underrepresented minority students' education.

por.por_cntn:
Phonons, as vibration quanta of a crystalline lattice, play a key role in almost every physical process. Therefore, understanding and even harnessing phonons and the interplay between different phonon modes is essential for controlling related physical processes. Ultimately, learning how to tailor phonon spectrum through materials design, for example by control of interface topology, should lead to desired physical property and device functionality with optimum performance. The overall aim of this NSF award was to gain an improved understanding of how nanoscale interface can enable unique phonon coupling and engineering by combining recent materials advancement of precisely tailored hybrid nanostructures and femtosecond time-resolved optical spectroscopy, and then elucidating the interplay between different phonon modes and fundamental phonon-mediated spin dynamics through recent development of coherent phonon and spin control in the time domain.

This NSF award was highly interdisciplinary, spanning from nanomaterials advancement, simulation to ultrafast optical study. In brief, during the four-year grant period, we have made substantial progress in different areas: We have developed a theoretical model and finite element simulation method to understand interfacial acoustic phonon coupling at the nanoscale, that can allow us to understand and predict structure-dependent phonon modes and to compare with experiment; We have advanced new bottom-up morphology imprinting synthetic method to control anisotropy of hybrid nanostructures that can be used as new test beds for experimental study of nanoscale phonons through interfacial coupling; We have developed various ultrafast optical spectroscopy techniques to achieve time-domain control of phonons in a highly selective manner; We have initiated ultrafast optical experiments to study roles of phonons in nanoscale spin decoherence process by combining all-optical spin excitation and detection with interfacial phonon generation. This NSF award has led to fruitful research outcomes and has generated much publicity by publishing results in high-profile journals and delivering many invited and plenary presentations in international conferences, workshops and institutions. As a brief summary, this award has so far directly led to publications in Science (1), Phys.Rev.Lett. (1 and 1 in-preparation), Nature Communications (1),  J.Am.Chem.Soc. (1), Nano Lett. (1), Nature Nano (1 submitted), Nature Physics (1 submitted), ACS Nano (1 under review).

As a broad impact, this NSF award has resulted in one invention disclosure for technology transformation. In addition to research findings, another important accomplishment of this NSF award is educational and outreach activities. During the grant periods, two graduates have successfully passed their thesis defenses. One woman undergraduate student who was supported by this NSF award for her undergraduate research was admitted to graduate school to continue her contribution to the STEM field. One of the undergraduate research team (Team META) under the supervision of the PI (and was partially supported by this NSF award) has won the best poster award in campus wide research competition, which highlights the quality and development of students under support of this NSF award. Lastly this NSF award has also support curriculum development of advanced undergraduate course on topic of nanoscience and nanotechnology.
